column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
jrun74, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have degenerative disk disease, scoliosis, and have already had neck surgery @C5 &C6 and I have tried robaxin(which didn't work at all), flexeril(which only made me sleepy), and baclofen which made me feel a little dizzy and drunk, but didn't help.  So far it's not been a whole week on the Soma, but it seems to be quite effective and I do get a much deeper sleep and wake up in the morning feeling quite well, which normally NEVER happens.  I was afraid to use this due to my mother being addicted to it years ago, but with having back problems similar to hers, I realize now why she took them.  I am only taking one pill at bedtime and 1 vicodin 2X a day.  I am hoping my body doesn't get used to it all and then i'll need more to get rid of the pain.

column2: Rwd681, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I quite agree with most of the comments listed on here.soma is one of the best muscle relaxers on the market. I noticed a couple of commemts about usimg them with narcotics. Use with vicoden/norco/then add a xanax (you might want to start by halfing the pills). This is what they call the three amigos. A very powerful cocktail and not to be taken lightly. But if ur having trouble controlling pain, well it works. But also the reason the FDA has changed the classification of the drug. Lets just say soma is being watched carefilly by tje FDA. Sorry for the typing, phone touchscreen isn't easy for me. Good luck to all with chronic pain. Been there simce 2007. Love and best wishes to all.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been diagnosed with Degenerative Disc Disease.  I have had two Cervical fusions with neither one helping much. I have been fighting chronic pain since 1999 when I had the first fusion.  After the second one the pain increased five fold.  I have tried a myriad of medications and Soma has been a godsend. I take it along side another pain medication and together they work better than anything so far.  I don't think that there is anything that will cure the pain totally and sometimes it is so bad that even the current meds don't help.  But overall it helps around 80% of the time.  I just received a letter from my Ins that Soma will not be covered by them next year and that they want me to try Tizanidine, which I have just been reading about.  Lots of people are saying it causes hallucinations and dry mouth, two things that I am not willing to give a try.  If I have to pay for my Soma myself then I will.

column2: dservn, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: if hurting it relieves muscle tightning if needed i may take 2 but makes me feel like a wet spaggettie noodle so use caution when taking

column2: jackalopesforal, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I haven't had much luck with this muscle relaxer, which I was given for herniated disc pain. My doctors all seem to want me to take the muscle relaxer even though I have not had any spasms. This medication does nothing for my pain, but it does put me to sleep for 3 hours, which is sometimes desirable. However, if you doc says you should take this during the daytime, as mine have, I doubt you will be very happy with it. There is no way to get any work done, or even to walk further than your bathroom (I hope you don't have stairs between your bed and bath, for that matter) on this med, at least in my case. Not only does it put me directly to sleep, no matter what my pain level is, but I end up sleeping in horrible positions that exacerbate my pain and I wake up feeling almost hung-over- very groggy, headachey, moody and with greater pain. My doctors keep pushing it on me for my pain, so maybe I should just read them this review to get them to understand that I hate this drug. I do want to stress, having said all this, that I don't have muscle spasms, so it may just be my doctors' ignorance that has lead me to take this drug, and not a possibility for benefit.

column2: abgirlee, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have suffered in pain from a car accident 14 years ago that I ended up with disc herniations and fibromyalgia from and Soma is the only pain medicine that makes life bearable. I usually only take one a day, at night. I've been on it for many years and haven't found it to be habit forming (if I don't need it I don't take it with no withdrawal symptoms) or to cause any side effects. This drug is a miracle for me. Might be helpful for other people suffering with Fibromyalgia because of the muscle relaxing effects.

misslady, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I, like many of you here, have been in multiple car accidents (thanks you speeding LA schmucks) and have recently had the titanium plate and screws removed from left fibula due to constant agony from pressure changes. Between the spinal injuries and the legs deal, I'm in constant pain and to my Dr.'s amusement, won't take narcotic pain relievers at all. Soma has literally turned my life in a complete 180. I'm not short, grumpy and agitated, trying to plot a way to stay in bed because I ache. I'm up going places, getting crap done and trying to do charity work! I'm with the old man, if it kills me, well then I'll die knowing I lived.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: This medicine has helped me a lot with my neuropathy episodes that cause pain, severe cramping, and lack of sleep. I take either one 350 mg or just a half pill at night before bedtime. It has helped me sleep and seems to prevent the cramping spasms at night.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I get migranes all the time. No doctor could find a pain med that would help, and I got them sometimes for a week straight. After seeing a specialist in Boston he perscribed soma. As long as I take at least 2 and go to bed it usually works. If I take more than 3 in a day it makes me sick. It can be very addicting, so I try to watch how much I rely on it so I dont run into any problems. When I have migranes, these pills take the pain away so I no longer have migranes for days and days and days. Life saver!

column2: 65-74 Female  (Patient)
column9: 69yrs young- had back surgery March 24,2008.have titanium pins in lower back- had deathin family- drove cross country- this drug has been a life saver for me. Only take it when back spasm happens- maby once a wk.

column2: MichaelMasters, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have taken Soma (Carisoprodol) for 12 years. According to the medical society, I abuse it as I take up to 10, 350mg tablets a day. They tell me it is addicting, if so, I don't care. Doctors will give me 12 extra strenght Vicodin (narcotic) a day with 4 Soma and think nothing of it. When I tell them I don't want the Vicodin, just give me more Soma, they get spasdic. I don't get it. Soma may kill me, it may not, but it keeps me going without surgery and without narcotics. Therefore, if it is addictive, so be it. I am 60 years old, in pain with severe muscle spasms, doc says I need surgery, I say screw you. Therefore I get Soma from my doctor and from anyplace that has brick walls and calls themselves a pharmacy and has a license to dispense medicine hanging on their wall. Maybe, and only just maybe, those under 40 years old maybe should be careful about taking certain drugs. But for me, Soma works, I can function on it, so I will take it. Preferably the Medical Society, Doctors, etc. will get onboard and stop worrying about it and start worrying more about narcotics. NUFF SAID!

column2: kathyj, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had major back problems with pain and was told, at age 46, that I needed a hip replacement by age 50. I am now 49. The hip condition is congenital; many females in my family line have needed/had one. However, when I insisted my back be X-rayed, my Orthopaedic Surgeon was surprised at how bad it looked; I had spinal surgery (3-07) with several vertabrae fused. I recovered with Oxycodone, then with Hydrocodone and Carisoporodol and it was very helpful.  I ended up taking just the Carisoprodol, as the Hydrocodone was somewhat irritating to my thought process and stomach/gastrical tract, and I am off altogether with the exception of a few I have left over.>>K.E. Seattle, Wa.

column9: Since I have osteporosis throught, including mainly my larger joints such as both hips, knees, ankles (after a fall from a tree in 1995 crushing the RT Calcanius), Both shoulders and wrist, Lower back @ L-4 & L-5 (older fall never corrected herniated disc).
